db:abstract.db:para: Overview of how to use the SocketCAN plugin.

db:article.db:para: The SocketCAN plugin encapsulates the Linux sockets API for accessing the CAN devices. This API is a set of open source CAN drivers and a networking stack contributed by Volkswagen Research to the Linux kernel.
This plugin requires a Linux Kernel with SocketCAN support and SocketCAN device drivers for the used CAN hardware.

db:section.db:title: SocketCAN usage
db:section.db:para: To list all (including unconfigured) network interfaces, the command ifconfig -a can be used.
To use SocketCAN, the corresponding Linux Kernel modules must be loaded and the network interface must be configured.

db:section.db:title: Setting up real CAN hardware
db:section.db:para: This section assumes, that the device driver is already loaded (most likely automatically when connecting the CAN hardware).

db:section.db:title: Default settings
db:section.db:para: To set the device can0 to a bitrate of 250 kBit/s:
db:section.db:programlisting: sudo ip link set up can0 type can bitrate 250000
db:section.db:para: To automatically recover from "bus off" errors after 100 milliseconds, the following command can be used:
db:section.db:programlisting: sudo ip link set up can0 type can bitrate 250000 restart-ms 100

db:section.db:title: CAN FD settings
db:section.db:para: To set the device can0 to an arbitration bitrate of 500 kBit/s and a data bitrate of 4 MBit/s (for frames with bitrate switch flag):
db:section.db:programlisting: sudo ip link set can0 up type can bitrate 500000 dbitrate 4000000 fd on

db:section.db:title: Setting up a virtual CAN bus

db:note.db:para: For CAN FD usage, the MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit) has to be set to 72 byte.

db:section.db:programlisting: sudo modprobe vcan sudo ip link add dev vcan0 type vcan sudo ip link set up vcan0 mtu 72
db:section.db:para: The command line test programs used in the following are from the can-utils package:
db:section.db:programlisting:
# Display received CAN messages with absolute timestamps and flags candump -ta -x vcan0
# Send a CAN FD message with flags BRS and EFI set cansend vcan0 123##3112233445566778899aabbccddeeff
# Generate random CAN messages cangen vcan0

SocketCAN supports the following configurations that can be controlled through setConfigurationParameter():

db:td.db:para: To meet the multiple-user needs, the local loopback is enabled by default. This means, whenever a CAN frame is transmitted on the CAN bus, a local echo of this frame is sent to all applications connected to this CAN device. If this option is enabled, the therefore received frames are marked with QCanBusFrame::hasLocalEcho()

The reception of the CAN frames on the same socket that was sending the CAN frame is disabled by default. When enabling this option, all CAN frames sent to the CAN bus immediately appear in the receive buffer. This can be used to check if sending was successful. If this option is enabled, the therefore received frames are marked with QCanBusFrame::hasLocalEcho()

A CAN interface driver can generate so called Error Message Frames that can optionally be passed to the user application in the same way as other CAN frames. The possible errors are divided into different error classes that may be filtered using the appropriate error mask. The values for the error mask are defined in linux/can/error.h.
This configuration can contain multiple filters of type QCanBusDevice::Filter. By default, the connection is configured to accept any CAN bus message.

Determines the bit rate of the CAN bus connection. The following bit rates are supported: 5000, 10000, 20000, 33000, 47000, 50000, 83000, 95000, 100000, 125000, 250000, 500000, 800000, 1000000. Note that this configuration parameter can only be adjusted while the QCanBusDevice is not connected. To set this configuration parameter, the library libsocketcan is needed at runtime http://www.pengutronix.de/software/libsocketcan Usually, root rights are needed to set the CAN bus bitrate.
This configuration option determines whether CANFD frames may be sent or received. By default, this option is disabled. It controls the CAN_RAW_FD_FRAMES option of the CAN socket.
This configuration is not supported by the socketcan plugin. However it is possible to set the data rate when configuring the CAN network interface using the ip link command.
Allows to use another protocol inside the protocol family PF_CAN. The default value for this configuration option is CAN_RAW (1).
